bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, November 17, 1875

div1.p: Reed describes a dinner given for General Humphreys, Chief of the Army Corps of Engineers. He also describes city sights seen with his brother. He gives a defense of army life and teases her.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, November 17, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
Novr 17th 75.

div1.p:
As I wrote
only about a dozen lines in
my last letter, I will write to-day,
& not wait till Tomorrow. I was
very much ashamed of myself
for not writing a longer letter &
had been upbraiding myself there-
for, when lo! behold, I find that
a certain young lady, whose name
I refrain from mentioning, has
“gone and done likewise”. Ah! me,
I knew it would come to this! But
I will proceed with my letter.
In a former letter I told you
that the “Mess” had invited Genl-
Humphreys to dine with them, and
it remains for me to tell you
what a delightful evening we
had. (However, since you are be-
ing so highly entertained by the
gentlemen of N. I doubt whether
you will be interested in so
small a matter as a dinner-
party, & for all I know, you
may have tossed aside this letter
unread, to listen to the sighs &
promises of a “wealthy” young gentle-
man.) There were eighteen of us,
arrayed in our brightest. 2
generals, 2 majors, 1 captain,
11 Lieutenants & 2 civilians sat
at the Table. It would be in vain
for me to tell you of the num-
ber of choice & dainty dishes that
pressed the sideboard, till it lit-
erally groaned. We sat down at
6.30 P.M. & did not leave the table
till after 10 o'clock. About 9 ocl.
the wines were brought on, & we
all “fell to” till in such style
that our tongues were soon
loosened & vibrating in an in-
describable manner! All, except
mine. For a certain little angel's
sake, I abstained, only touching
my lips to the sparkling draughts
as the various toasts were
proposed & drunk. At 11 o'clock
we all dispersed & sought our
quarters, feeling satisfied that we
had spent a most agreeable eve-
ning. The following morning, I went
to the City, expecting to meet my
brother, but after a thorough
search I found that he had de-
layed in Norfolk till Saturday.
Monday, I again went down to
shake his hand, & this time, was
successful. The day was a disagree-
able one, but I immediately set
out with him to see the sights.
From 10 a.m. till 2 P.M, we were bus-
ily travelling- At the latter hour, I sat
him down at the House of the
young lady who was to be mar-
ried at 5 P.M. Calling at 6 P.M.
I found that the ceremony had
passed off uninterruptedly & the
happy couple had departed for
the train. Jumping into a carriage
we were quickly driven to the Fer-
ry & were as soon aboard the
Cars for Whitestone & at 8 P.M.
reached the Post. In the morning, we
were off by 8 o'clock & in the City
by 9.30. Although the weather was
wretched- rain falling all day long-
I never checked my course till 11
P.M- showed him the Stock Exchange-
the Gold Room- Trinity church- (climbed
to the top of its steeple)- the New P.O.
building- Stewart's Store- Central
Park- Mosdy & Saukey- etc, etc.
This morning he left City at 9 o'clock &
I hastened home, weary & worn,
to write to you. Reaching home, I
found a surprisingly long epistle,
to a few parts of which, please allow
me to make reference. You say that
some, who pretend friendship, have
been telling you of the “horrors” of the
Army. Now, my little Sweetheart,
will you convey my compliments
to those “friends” & tell them that I
am much obliged to them for their
kindness & especially for talking of
affairs concerning which they know
absolutely nothing. Tell them,(& I hold
myself responsible for what I say,)
that the “horrors” of the Army are all
a myth & only known to those who
know nothing of Army life. Tell them,
morever, that I would not take you from
your home, did I not know that you
will go to as comfortable a home
as any young lady that ever left
Murfreesboro-- and that you will be
surrounded -- by just as many
comforts, & supported by as strong
an arm! Really, it almost nauseates
me when I hear people talk of
the dreadful life of an Army Officer
& especially the sad lot of his wife -- and this from
the very people who would only
be too happy & proud to receive
an offer from the same source!
Why, my darling, don't let them talk
to you, as if you were taking upon
yourself the life of a slave! As if
you were resigning friends, com-
forts & happiness! As if you were
going to live forever upon the
borders of Civilization & never
enjoy enlightened society! As if
you were joining yourself to a
man who can't provide sub-
sistence for you & of whom you
should be ashamed! When they
make such assertions, ask them for
the proofs- (one case would establish
the truth of what they say) & see how
very quickly such “friends” will sub-
side! Up to the present time, I have
met several ladies, wives of Army
officers, & unless I am much
mistaken, they seem to enjoy life
as much as any ladies whom
I have ever met.

So there is a “wealthy” young gen-
tleman who might make you
happy, if you were not “fet-
tered”. I pray you, do not let
me stand in the way of wealth
& happiness! Although you are
slightly fettered, think of the
“horrors” that await you, before
turning a deaf ear to him! He
has everything that heart can de-
sire, perhaps, & you could live
in the City of Norfolk. How very
pleasant that would be! Miserable
mortal that I am! to have been
born poor! Yeh, thank Heaven,!
the word “wealth” doesn't give
me as much anxiety as it does
others. Give me enough for my
ordinary wants, & a clean con-
science, & I ask no more.
Concerning your correspondence
with the Baltimore gentleman,
of course, I have nothing to say,
other than to remark, that you
must allow your own judge-
ment to decide whether it is
proper to correspond with a
gentleman who does not so
much as ask a correspondence,
but goes upon the assumption
that you will answer his letter.
Should you conclude to share
a part of your leisure moments with him
I trust that you will not forget
to occassionally write to your
own fond & devoted,
